1. Free Primary Education: In 2000, Lesotho introduced a policy of free primary education, which has helped to increase enrolment and retention rates.

2. Infrastructure Development: The Government has allocated funds to construct new schools and classrooms in rural areas, as well as refurbish the existing ones. A lot of emphasis has been given to the development of classrooms, libraries, laboratories, and other facilities that are necessary for quality education.

3. Teacher Training: The Government of Lesotho has launched various initiatives designed to improve the quality of its teachers. These initiatives include train-the-trainer programs, mentoring programs, and professional development opportunities.

4. Curriculum Development: The Government has been working to review and develop the curriculum in line with international standards. The new curriculum emphasizes competency-based learning and has been designed to prepare students for the world of work.

5. ICT in Education: Lesotho has formed partnerships with international organizations and private companies to provide access to technology and e-learning resources. This has made it possible to introduce new teaching and learning methods and improve access to education materials in remote areas.

6. Bursaries and Scholarships: Lesotho has implemented various scholarship and bursary programs that aim to assist vulnerable and disadvantaged groups in gaining access to education. The government provides scholarships to deserving students to study in local and international universities.

7. Adult Education Programs: Lesotho also provides adult education programs to ensure that citizens who missed out on formal education can still acquire basic literacy and numeracy skills. This includes classroom-based instruction and distance learning programs.
